Award.AwardTitle: U.S. Participation in the Centre de Recerca Matematica Research Program Operator Algebras: Dynamics and Interactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposal requests funding to help defray the expenses of U.S. participants in the research program "Operator Algebras: Dynamics and Interactions" that will be held at the Centre de Recerca Matematica (CRM) in Barcelona, Spain from March 1 - July 21, 2017. Additional information is available on the CRM website http://www.crm.cat/en/Activities/Curs_2016-2017/Pages/IRP-OAL.aspx

The CRM program is motivated by an important and recent complete classification, in K-theoretic data, of a broad class of C*-algebras with finite noncommutative topological dimension. The program will capitalize on this development by concentrating efforts on those nuclear C*-algebras arising from and with applications to topological dynamical systems and related areas such as topological groupoids. It is important that the next generation of U.S. researchers be informed of the state-of-the art and future of this field. This award will enable the participation of graduate students, junior researchers, underrepresented groups and other U.S. based researchers without support to participate in this meeting. This program will have significant impact in the field of C*-algebras and the future careers of junior investigators.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award helped defray the expenses of U.S. participants in the research program "Operator Algebras: Dynamics and Interactions" that was held at the Centre de Recerca Matematica (CRM) in Barcelona, Spain from March 1 - July 21, 2017. This five-month program brought leading experts from around the world to give workshops, seminar talks, conference presentations and collaborate on research. It was an outstanding opportunity for researchers in the United States to disseminate their own work, learn about cutting-edge results and reap the benefits of international collaboration. A particular emphasis was put on ensuring participation from early-career researchers, who typically do not have financial support for international research trips, and women and other under-represented demographics in mathematics. In the end, this award supported 17 U.S. mathematicians, with over 80% of funds going to early-career researchers, women or those from under-represented groups. As such, it represents an important contribution to the future diversity and vitality of the mathematical research community in the United States. 

Scientifically, the CRM program was a hub of activity and progress on questions related to a recent breakthrough in Elliott's Classification Program. Specifically, emphasis was placed on understanding when C*-algebras arising from dynamical systems and related areas such as topological groupoids have finite noncommutative topological dimension. There has been a flurry of activity in this area in recent years; the CRM program helped focus researchers around the world, bringing together the skill sets and expertise needed for further breakthroughs. A number of research papers grew out of participation in the CRM program, which speaks to the success and importance of the program. For a detailed list of papers produced by U.S. researchers supported by this award, please see the full final report.
